channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Death Toll in Pakistan Heat Wave Tops 650, Officials Say
item.description: Hospitals declared a state of emergency and the provincial authorities closed schools and some offices in Karachi, where temperatures have risen as high as 112 degrees Fahrenheit.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: NATO Returns Its Attention to an Old Foe, Russia
item.description: Military training exercises this month in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, underline the seismic shift for an alliance that had been focused on threats far beyond its borders.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of a British Gurkha regiment carried a Javelin antitank missile launcher during exercises this month in Adazi, Latvia. Troops from 14 countries took part.

item.title: Britain Holds Rwanda Spy Chief on Spanish War Crimes Charges
item.description: The Rwandan intelligence chief, Karenzi Karake, is wanted on war crimes charges involving genocide and the killing of Spanish aid workers in the 1990s.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Yulin Journal: Chinese City Defends Dog Meat Festival, Despite Scorn
item.description: Yulin, home of an annual dog meat festival, has become the target of a growing animal rights campaign, making its residents feel increasingly under siege.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dogs on sale for eating and as pets at a market in Yulin, China.

item.title: Obama Ordering Changes in U.S. Hostage Policies
item.description: Families of captives that try to raise ransom money for groups like the Islamic State will no longer face the threat of prosecution, officials say.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Diane Foley, mother of the slain hostage James Foley, met with President Obama in April.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Opens New Land Route to Tibet for Indian Pilgrims
item.description: The crossing on Monday of Nathu La signaled the official opening of a new pilgrimage route for Indians to the holy sites of Mount Kailash and Lake Manasarovar.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Two 8-year-old American girls on the Kailash pilgrimage trail with Indian tourists in orange jackets.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Preparations Proceed for China’s World War II Parade
item.description: The country has released new details for a large military procession in the heart of Beijing to commemorate the 70th anniversary of the end of the war.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: Helicopters flew in formation above a residential compound in Beijing on June 12 as part of a training session for the parade commemorating the war's end.

item.title: Itineraries: AirAsia Faces Red Tape and Tough Competition in India
item.description: AirAsia has exported its low-cost model to India, hoping to catch its hundreds of millions in first-time fliers. The move has proven harder than expected.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MAX BEARAK
item.media:credit: Sami Siva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mittu Chandilya, chief executive of AirAsia India, beside one of its aircraft in Delhi. The low-cost airline aims to capture a growing market in India.

item.title: North Korea Sentences 2 From South to Life Over Spying
item.description: The North accused the men of trying to undermine its government on behalf of South Korea and the United States.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Pro-Democracy Demonstrators Decamp in Hong Kong
item.description: The authorities posted notices at a tent site where protesters have been based for nine months, instructing them to leave by Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters packing up to leave the tent city outside government headquarters in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: 3 Little Words Drive Wedge Between Britain and Rest of E.U.
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron is pushing for an end to a pledge written into European treaties for an “ever closer union.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain has promised to secure a “better deal” from the European Union before holding a referendum by the end of 2017 on whether to drop out.

item.title: Singapore Court Wants Teenage Blogger Held for Psychiatric Review
item.description: Amos Yee, 16, drew worldwide attention after his arrest for posting a video criticizing Lee Kuan Yew after the Singaporean leader’s death.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Amos Yee, 16, leaving court in Singapore in May after his conviction on charges of obscenity and insulting religious feelings. A court ruled on Tuesday that he should be held for two weeks pending a psychiatric examination.

item.title: Guggenheim Helsinki Unveils Design
item.description: The winning design, by the husband-and-wife firm Moreau Kusunoki Architectes, was chosen from 1,715 anonymous submissions.
item.dc:creator: ROBIN POGREBIN
item.media:description: A rendering of the winning design for the new Guggenheim Helsinki. The museum complex is at center.

item.title: South Korean Novelist Apologizes in Wake of Plagiarism Accusation
item.description: Shin Kyung-sook, whose novel “Please Look After Mom” won the Man Asian Literary Prize in 2011, said she may have plagiarized material for a short story decades ago.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Republican Case for Obama’s Cuba Policy
item.description: Cuban-Americans and the G.O.P. must look to the future instead of the past. Ordinary Cubans need trade and engagement, not more isolation.
item.dc:creator: CARLOS M. GUTIERREZ

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Iran Deal’s Fatal Flaw
item.description: It won’t actually buy us more time if Tehran decides to build a bomb.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: ALAN J. KUPERMAN

item.title: U.S. and China Set to Meet, With Few Expectations
item.description: The fact that top officials of the two nations are talking, at a two-day meeting in Washington, is seen as positive at a time when they seem far apart.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Samsung Heir Apparent Apologizes for Hospital’s Role in MERS Outbreak
item.description: Lee Jae-yong, who is being groomed to run the South Korean conglomerate, made a televised apology for a Samsung hospital’s failures in dealing with the outbreak.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. and China Set to Meet, With Few Expectations
item.description: The fact that top officials of the two nations are talking, at a two-day meeting in Washington, is seen as positive at a time when they seem far apart.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE CALMES

item.title: Four Prominent Chilean Politicians Are Charged With Tax Fraud
item.description: These are the first politicians to appear before a court as prosecutors unravel a high-profile corruption case related to illegal campaign financing.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY
